item.description:
A mathematical card game. The cards feature somewhere interesting in Sunderland, which is in the northeast of England.

Each card has a number between 0 and 9, except for the Double cards. Each player gets 6 cards and must look to see if a pair can be formed. A pair is made up of two numbers that, when multiplied together, make a total that is also on one of the two cards. For instance, you play a 5 and an 8 which makes 40. Thus the number 40 must also be on one of the two cards played. If successful, a pair is formed and can be laid face-up in front of the player. The first player to lay three pairs (6 cards) wins the round.

When a round is one, the other players add up the value of the cards in their hand and that is their score. After 12 rounds, the lowest score is the winner.

There are special rules for the Double Cards which you need to play because if you are caught with them in your hand when a player goes out, you get a nasty negative score.

This is an expanded game (but more subtle and a better design of the cards) that first appeared as Multitu in the 1960's.

A mathematical card game which first appeared in 1964. The cards feature numbers and you must form pairs. A pair consist of a total on one of the two cards that is equalled when the two cards played are multiplied together.

If you use all your cards first, the round ends and the player going out scores nothing but the other players take a negative score based on the cards still in their hands.

To spice up play, there are Problem Cards which are nasty if you get caught with them in your hand when another player goues out. One of them is Mr Whacker, a school teacher who seems to like caning his pupils.

In a foreboding castle somewhere in central Europe, a strange fear has descended upon the inhabitants. One morning the body of a young girl was found, as pale as a sheet of paper, dry and totally drained of blood. Vampires are on the prowl! Who is the monster who murders innocent during the night? Before the truth will be discovered, more than one person may face unjust accusations thrown out by the devious servants of darkness. Will the vampires be successfully caught before they endanger the entire society, or will the castle and city fall forever into darkness?

Three characters in the castle are vampires. A human investigator is trying to determine which three of nine characters he encounters are, in fact, monsters hiding in human form so that he can eliminate them. The head vampire, on the other hand, must bluff cleverly, present confusing clues, and trick the humans into attacking innocent citizens. By doing this, the vampire can kill the most important characters in the city or conquer the castle.

Vampire Empire is a two-player card game with a lot of bluffing and player interaction. In this very thematic setting, each player possess a unique deck of cards granting different powers, and each player had different goals to win the game!

item.description:
Educational card game published by the British Diabetic Association. It is an attempt to make people think about what they eat, especially for them to know the calorie count of their meals.

In it's basic form, players can just ask each other about a card, for instance: " Find me another card with the same calorie count as X".
But two more interactive games are possible. In 'Shop Shut' (for which you need two copies of the game) each player gets a hand of cards. One player is nominated as the Caller. Everyone plays their cards face up in front of them. The Caller draws a card and if a player has the same card, he shouts "Sold" and turns the card over. This continues until one player turns over his last card and then shouts "Shop Shut". That player scores nothing but the other players score their cards still 'open' by totalling the Carbohydrates on the card (or the Calorie count if decided before the game begins). After a pre-agrred time limit expires, the player with the lowest score wins.

In 'Happy Food Families, it plays exactly the same as a Happy Families/Quartet/Authors game. A set of four cards must all be the same food value as indicated on the card. The player who has the most sets when the cards run out, wins.

Far in the future, war has been relegated to a spectator sport. As humanity has spread throughout the solar system, advances in material sciences have left us wanting for nothing yet craving new forms of entertainment.

3D printers ranging in size from minuscule to mammoth process material known as Nano-Goo (or just “Goo”) into virtually anything a person could need, from food and clothing to massive, space-faring ships. Using these technologies, a few enterprising individuals capitalized on humanity’s need for entertainment and have brought back to life the ancient custom of gladiatorial combat -- done safely by remotely operating (teleoperating) vastly powerful machines of war known as War Bots.

Large 3D printing structures are dropped onto remote asteroids and other small, celestial bodies. These come with a small complement of devices which begin to process the raw materials of these asteroids into Goo, which these massive printers can use to create War Bots. Printers use a series of programs called .WAR Files, which give them the specifics of War Bots which they can then use Goo to print.

War Bots are printed out of Goo, which is programmed to take a specific form with specific functions. Because they are made of self organizing nanomaterials, War Bots can be modified by simple programs called .UPGrade Files – or upgrades. These upgrades can be applied to War Bots while they are in the field.

Governed by a strict set of rules, and limited by the programs made available to them, contestants manufacture and then fight with these giant machines, for the delight of audiences throughout the Solar System.

Upgrade Wars is a deck building, tactical combat game. Players begin the game with a starter deck of 10 resources and two War Bots (the giant robots that do the actual fighting).

Through the course of the game, they may purchase new programs to deploy as War Bots or to Upgrade existing War Bots that have already been deployed.

The battle field is divided into three zones - the Printer zone (where the magic happens), the Defensive Ring and the Front Line - a zone shared by all players.

Your bots traverse the battlefield under your command in an attempt to reach other player's printers and destroy them.

Complete Victory: The last player with a Printer still capable of creating War Bots wins the game!
Tactical Victory: Each enemy War Bot you destroy is worth 1 Victory Point. Each enemy Printer is worth 5 Victory Points. Once three card piles are depleted, the player with the most Victory Points wins!

Featuring strategic and tactical play - players must decide where and when to spend their resources, which can go to either purchasing new program files or deploying War Bots into the field of battle. At the same time, you must manage your existing War Bots to defend your Printer and attack the enemy.

item.description:
After millennia of shifting dominant civilizations, wars and industrialization, Homeworld became a planet that couldn’t sustain its population... Off-world migration was the last hope. When your Homeworld is nearing its demise, it is time to saddle up your rocket ship and explore the neighborhood in nearby space.

PARSEC is a tile placement game of discovery and exploration in outer space for 2 to 4 players. Featuring easy mechanics and a nimble pace, Parsec is a truly teachable game for everyone. It boasts rich, compelling Euro-style competitive gameplay as each player races to improve their positions to garner the most points and technology progress between scoring rounds. Careful placement of drawn tiles featuring sections of planets, nebulae, asteroid fields, and more is half the game, while maneuvering your rocket and carefully assigning its compliment of robots for control of these key locations is equally important. Asteroids and a presence on opponent-dominated Planets garner Credits used to purchase additional actions. After the last Planet is completed, a final scoring round takes place and the winner determined.

This is your chance to save the denizens of Homeworld; explore PARSEC today!

Note: PARSEC DELUXE includes Parsec and its first two expansions: Moons and Monsters (#1), and Nebulas and Nanotechs (#2).

Game Data:
Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 3 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each player commands a ship full of robots exploring the space around their declining homeworld

link.value: Parsec Expansion Kit 1: Moons and Monsters
Parsec Expansion Kit 2: Nebulas and Nanotechs

item.description:
Axia — a land with a glorious past, a most uncertain present, and an even more unpredictable future. Populated by what has been described as a fervent and warm-blooded people, Axia is in crisis – economic, social, and political: the longest-running recession in its modern history, the highest inequality in years, and a political system teetering on the brink of collapse.

In more ways than one, Axia is fighting against itself. Old divisions of the past have given way to new ones, and this generation – along with the next ones – has the most to lose.

Will you, along with your fellow industrialists, do your part to help Axia? Will you sacrifice short-term gain in the present for a brighter future? Can you do that, and survive? Perhaps you can, and perhaps you can even thrive – and you will, if you see opportunity where others only see crisis!

CRISIS is a turn-based game for 1-5 players who assume the roles of businessmen, trying to rebuild their businesses and create value at a particularly challenging time. By skillfully placing their managers in a position to invest in companies, trade resources, and navigate the local bureaucracy and regulations, they can thrive and prosper in a time when others might struggle and decline.

name.value: Bump N Run the Stock Car Racing Board Game

item.description:
Bump N Run is a roll and move style game played on an oval race track/game board with 3 racing lanes. each player rolls the dice to determine the starting order. Highest roller is 1st, next highest 2nd, and so on up to 8 players. Each player starts the game with 10 fuel tokens, 4 tire tokens,and 4 Bump n Run cards. Then you decided on how many laps to run(5,10,20,etc). 
 
Each player, in turn rolls the dice and moves there car/pawn around the board space by space, lane to lane wherever they choose. Every time you roll the dice it cost you 1 fuel token, every time you change lanes it cost you 1 tire token. when you come up on another car/player you have the choice to race around him, or race to through him by playing a Bump R Run card, which knocks him back to where your turn started.
 
When you get low on fuel or tires you race in to the pits to spin the pit wheel to earn money to buy more fuel, tires, and Bump N Run cards. You spin the wheel once per turn and stay as many turns as you need to. 
 
Every time you complete a lap of the track/board you collect a lap counter card to keep score. The first player to complete a pre-determined number of laps is the winner.

In this trivia game, on your turn you will answer your question with 1 to 3 possible answers. The other players then vote using their cards whether the correct answer is #1, #2, #3, or "None of the Above." The active player gets 3-5 points if he's right, more points if he wrote fewer answers. The other players get 2 points if they guess correctly.

If players don't feel they can accurately guess, they can "cheat." They can look at the answer, get only 1 point that round, and must include the correct answer in the three they write on the board.

In 1894, farmers from the small village of Malpaso face the prospect of again losing their livelihood to a band of roving thieves, led by the self-styled "General" Mapache – himself wanted by the Mexican National Defense Army.

Their solution is to go to the much admired but fallen from grace "Padre" Esteban, and see whether he can hire gunfighters to protect them. After trying to raise funds by any means at the "All Rivers" Poker tournament, the Padre recruits a band of gunslingers for the task and, once complete, travels back to the village over the precipitous Los Quantos bridge – all the while harassed by a detachment of the General's men. There they fortify Malpaso itself, and usher the frightened villagers into the abandoned silver mine for protection.

When the bandits finally attack, both sides are prepared. Mapache's men unleashing their Gatling gun to devastating effect, while the villagers have a few tricks of their own. Both sides will suffer many casualties in the calamitous battle, but will the Mexican Army arrive in time to put an end to the bloodshed?

Revolver 2: Last Stand at Malpaso is a two-player card game set in the Old West, in which one player takes the role of General Mapache and his band of thieving outlaws, and the other player controls the villagers and guardians hired to protect the town of Malpaso, led by the infamous Padre Esteban. Each player has a unique deck of cards with unique possibilities as well as different winning conditions, which requires different tactics and different methods of play.

More than just new locations, Revolver 2 features brand new gameplay elements in players can use a mine cart-mounted Gatling gun, blow up a bridge, assemble their own team of gunfighters, and dynamite mine tunnels. The game also includes a terrific Stud Poker mini-game which determines in which town the initial firefights occur.

Like the original Revolver, the game remains elegantly simple and can be learned in five minutes. That said, Revolver 2 is a standalone game and the cards from Revolver and its expansions (red packaging) are not interchangable with Revolver 2 and its expansions (green packaging).

item.description: The game can be played by 2 to 6 players. Goal of the game is to collect 6 Heineken stars as fast as possible. You collect a star by answering a question card right. The questions are about the history of the beer and about Heineken. That's how players learn about Heineken. The board is a worldmap. This is how players travel from continent to continent. To illustrate what kind of export product Heineken is. Heineken the game is educative, enervating and fast played!

This is a children's motorized action game. Part of a series of games entitled T.H.I.N.G.S. or Totally Hillarious Incredibly Neat Games of Skill. This is the outer space themed game Astro-Nots. The mission is to rescue the Astro-Nots from the moon surface by lowering the arm of the space ship. A magnet on the end of the space ship lifted the "Nots". The game was started by pulling the alien monster (attached via string) to wind up the game. When the monster was pulled back the game, the round was over. From the box: "Save the Astro-Nots from the Angry Alien!"Ages 5 and up for 1 or more players.

Year around soccer fun:

Comes with a game board, a set of dice,30 each of the following: Penalty Cards, Penalty Kick Cards and Corner Kick Cards

Object: Player with highest score wins

Designed for 2-4 players

Ages 4 and up

Players can lose the ball by landing on a pass blockers square, landing on a ball out of play square
landing on an offside square or by the results of a penalty card

Scoring Points can be accumulated by going completely around the board for 1 point or as a result of corner kicks or penalty kicks

First player to reach 20 points wins the game

name.value: Sesame Street Hunt, Chase, Swap and Race!

item.description:
This is a Sesame Street board game from 1985 made by Milton Bradley. There were 4 collectible game pieces included in the game that were displayed in a clear open window on the game box.

Object: Be first to return to START with three cards belonging to your Sesame Street Characters

Game Pieces: 1 Game board, 4 Sesame Street Playing Pieces, 24 Playing Cards, 1 Die and One Playing Cup (blue)

Collectible Game Pieces include: Big Bird, Cookie Monster, Bert and Ernie

Step inside a classic video arcade side-scrolling space shooter. Earth is once again at the mercy of on-coming waves of alien attack ships. Luckily, you have the one vessel that can defend the earth from the onslaught. Equipped with your all-important blaster, destroy wave after wave of alien ships and defeat the "Boss" at the end of each level, until the earth is once again safe.

Each Level of Blaster Waves is made up of a "Waves Round" and a "Boss Round". In a Waves Round, the dual-use cards in the main deck are used to setup waves of aliens attacking the player's ship, and also give the player a hand of cards for blasting away at those aliens. The blaster value on the card played from the player's hand is used to remove aliens in the attacking waves. Once the waves have been dispatched, the Boss Round starts where the player has a back-and-forth match with the Boss alien – with the Boss taking an action based on a reveal "Boss Action" card, and the player responding. If the player is able to defeat the Boss, the next Level begins. The player wins the game after defeating the Boss on Level 5.

The game includes Health indicators and PowerUps, such as shields, missiles, bombs, Health improvements, and even a "Wingman".

Card game played in South-Western France using a latin-suited card deck. This is an easy trick taking game for 2 or 4 players in partnerships where there is no trump suit and no obligation to follow suit. The winner of a trick, is the person who plays the highest ranking card. In the case of a tie, the trick is set aside, and the winner of the next trick takes both tricks. The object of the standard game is to get the most tricks. This game becomes much more interesting by aiming alternatively to get the three of Diamonds, or to avoid getting the Jack of Spades, which can be difficult tasks considering that not all cards are dealt to the players.

Trick Taking game for 4 players using the standard 52-card deck. Each player tries to take three tricks to get a maximum score. 
For 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,... tricks, the score will be -5,1,4,9,-4,-5,-6,... points are awarded, respectively.

As you can see, at least one player is to get 4 or more tricks, thus getting a negative points.

Three tricks is a simple fun game invented by Jun Kusaba (Zyun Kusaba).

There are two special dice and thirty-six cards in this game. 
In his turn player rolls the dice:
The first die shows six topics: boat, house, sun, apple snail, butterfly. The second die shows six colors.

Player who first grabs the card with the correct topic and color get that card as a point.
Player with the most points after all cards are taken is the winner.

Two players have shaped pieces with varied numbering. The player rolls special dice then, according to the visible faces, groups them together to form a coherent logical order or sequence on the gameboard, eg: "3-s": "a vertical box" "2 squares horizontal" etc. for score points.

Players must lead their locomotive to ten destinations. The gratings are formed of sequences of 1 or 0. The special dice contain only 1 and 0. Player rolls the dice and if they show by example 1-1-0, you may follow paths that meet the combinations 0-1-1, 1-0-1 or 1-1-0.

One of the three dice additionally carries a red face and a green face, for placement of traffic lights to prevent enemy movement with red or to clear the way with green light.

Who go through all of his destinations first is the winner.

name.value: Le chemin de compostelle (Le Jeu de Loupio)

item.description:
The goal is to reach St. Jacques de Compostela in the way that collected the necessary assets: generosity, courage, resourcefulness, knowledge etc.

Basically the game is a race from Assisi to Compostela, witt rolling the dice, but with hazards on the way and rewards for virtues such as 'courage' 'generosity' and 'knowledge'.

Who reaches the finish first is the winner.

name.value: Pax Porfiriana: Edición Deluxe en Español

item.description:
Pax Porfiriana – Latin for "The Porfirian Peace" – refers to the 33-year reign of dictator Porfirio Díaz, who ruled Mexico with an iron hand until toppled by the 1910 Revolution.

As a rich businessman (Hacendado) in the turbulent pre-revolutionary borderlands of the U.S. and Mexico, players compete to build business empires of ranches, mines, rails, troops, and banks while subverting opponents with bandidos, Indians, and lawsuits. Each turn goes as follows:

1. Action Phase: Perform three actions, such as play new cards, get new cards from the market, speculate on cards in the market, buy land, or redeploy troops.
2. Discard Headlines: Remove any Headlines (i.e. cards with the Bull-Bear icon) that have reached the leftmost position in the Market.
3. Restore Market: Restore the Market to twelve cards.
4. Income Phase: Collect one gold per Income, Extortion, and Connection Cube in play. If Depression, pay one gold for each card in play (includes Partners and Enterprises in your Row, and all of your Troops).

Four "scoring" cards (Toppling) are in the game and their effect depends on the current form of government. The government can change if troops are played and as a result of other cards. The form of government also influences different production values of the game, such as how much mines produce. Players win by toppling Díaz, either by coup, succession, revolution, or annexation of Mexico by the U.S. If Díaz remains firmly seated at the end of the game, then the player with the most gold wins.

Pax Porfiriana includes 220 cards, but only fifty cards (along with ten for each player) are used in a game, so no two games will be the same!

link.value: Lords of the Sierra Madre (second edition)

item.description:
The object of the game depends of the hero played by the child:
Peter Pan: save as many children or remove hook
Hook: capture a maximum number of children or remove Peter Pan

Each player will move one checker according to the illustration of the card he plays.
Depending on the clan he represents, he will try to bring this character of his hero or away from each other. It must reflect the specific character displacement (2, 4 or 8 possible directions, the right to capture another character or not).

To retrieve a child captured, only the Duel is possible only once per player per game. We then use all the cards of two players to do battle. When all cards have been played, the one possessing the highest number wins the Duel and the child may choose to switch sides.

The game ends when one of the following events:

 Peter Pan is captured
 Hook is captured
 All the lost children are out of the game (as they were captured or saved)

From Wikipedia
Seven Spades is a card game, apparently created by Johan Wästlund in 2002. It's similar to Bullshit in that bluffing plays a key role; however the game is more fast-paced and, arguably, more intense.

While originally intended for two players (which is still the best way to play it), any number of people can play.

The gameplay is simple. A deck of 52 cards is used. The dealer shuffles the deck and places it on the table face down. The player to the left of the dealer is the first to go - he picks up a card from the deck, taking care not to show it to anyone. Now he can either discard it on the table, face up, or declare it a spade and put it in front of him, face down. If the latter happened, any other player can, but is not obliged to, challenge the first player by opening the card. If it's not a spade (i.e. the player attempted bluff), the first player is out of the game; if it is a spade, the second player is out. When only one player is left, he is declared the winner; with two people playing, the winner will always be determined on the first challenge.

The only other way to win is to collect a pre-determined number of spades - seven spades in the two-player version. The last (seventh) spade has to be a real spade, and is put face up, not face down. The person to do this is declared the winner.

Anyone can challenge a person who claims to have a spade, but only immediately after the card is put down. When the next player picks up a card, you are no longer allowed to challenge the previous player. Only the last card a player put down can be challenged, not the other ones.

When more than two people are playing, the number of spades to collect is adjusted so that it's always possible to win without bluffing. With a single 52-card deck, the number of spades to collect is:

for 2 people: 7
for 3 people: 5
for 4 people: 4
for 5 people: 3

To increase the number of spades, or to allow more than five people to play, more than one deck can be used. The number of spades to collect is then multiplied by the number of decks used.

Optionally the following rule can be added when more than two people are playing: if a person challenges another player and proves him a liar, he gets a free turn. This promotes challenging and makes bluffing a bit more expensive.

Using the standard deck of cards, each player tries to have the fewest number of cards at the end of the game. All cards are spread out face-down in the middle of the game like the shape of "pig tail". Everyone starts with no cards in his/her hand. In your turn, you either flip a card or play a card from your hand. If it is different color and different number form the previous one, then it stays there. Otherwise you take all the face-up cards to your hand. The game is over when there is no face-down card in the middle of the table.

There are a lot of games with similar rules. This one is particularly strategic. As there are only 2 colors (black and red), you really want to time when you start decreasing the hand size. It is all about timing.

The game is strongly recommended for even number of players like 4 or 6. The game is nearly as good with 3 or 5.

item.description:
This is a traditional game in Fukui-prefecuture, Japan using the variant of Hanafuda cards called "Komatsu-Fudaï¼ˆå°æ¾æœ­ï¼‰". Each player tries to get rid of his/her hand of 6 cards. You can play as many card as you want in your turn provided they make the sequence continuing from the previous number. There are some other ways to play 2-3 cards of the same number at once. If you manage to play all 6 cards in one turn then you get double the game point.

The game only works with 7 players. If there are 8, then one person with a particular card sit out.

Parity is a trick taking game using the standard deck of cards. You get the number of points equal to the number of tricks you take. However, if the number of trick is odd, then your score is negative. Thus, for 0,1,2,3,4,5,... tricks, you get 0,-1,2,-3,4,-5,... points, respectively. Since there are 13 tricks, someone must have a negative score!

Ice floes filled with frozen weasels float by, and you must carefully chip them apart, pull out the furry popsicles, and defrost them. Be on your toes, though, because you don't want to get stuck with frozen monsters or miss your chance to grab the prized weaseltonium particles!

The game begins with a line of cards face up, representing an ice floe. Most of the cards depict a weasel frozen in the ice. On your turn, you may either chip one end off the ice flow and tow it away (take a card from one end of the line) or split the ice floe (separate the cards into two separate lines). If you have collected a matching trio of frozen weasels, you may thaw them to take an extra turn and score more points.

More cards are laid out as the game progresses. Preference cards make particular weasels worth more or less, so part of the strategy is keeping the other players from getting varieties they like while forcing them to take monsters.

item.description:
Toulon 1793 is an operational level game covering the siege of Toulon, in the South of France, between 25 August and 21 December, 1793. It’s an area based system covering the entire campaign from the initial landing by Anglo-Spanish forces (at the invitation of the rebel Toulonnais) through to their evacuation of the town as their ships came under threat from the batteries of the previously unknown Napoleon Bonaparte.

Operation points are at the heart of the system and combined with an innovative combat, loss and movement system generate a vast number of decision points for the players. Chrome comes in the form of spies, gendarmes, multi-national forces (and associated cooperation issues), reconnaissance, variable reinforcements and much more. The game covers an area from Ollioules in the West to Sollies in the East and from Mount Farron in the North to Cap Cepet in the South.

NOW SHIPPING

item.description:
Trick-taking game for mostly 4 players. It is played in Prisdorf, Germany area. Using 25 cards (A,10,K,Q,J,9,8,7 from non-Diamonds and 7 of Diamond), the game is played like an easy version of Skat.

For 4-player game, players are dealt 5 cards. Among the remaining 5 cards, 3 of them are not used and 2 of them are placed face down in the middle of the table. Each player bids the number of tricks they can take with their choice of the trump suit. The game value is equal to these number of tricks called. Each of the following causes to double the game value: by not using the face-down cards (Hand game), by choosing a diamond as a trump (called "Ruten" - notice that there is only one diamond card in the deck), or by bidding 5 (called Durch).

There are also some special bids. Kieker is like null and he can use all 5 face-down cards to exchange his hand. Siebener Fips is the case to have all four 7s and an Ace.

Psight refers to a collective of psychics founded by the gifted Clairvoyant known as The Seer. With the aid of a powerful Telepath (Psi-Guardian) she sought out others of various talents to swell their ranks. She organized them in preparation for a war she foresaw hundreds of years into the future. The Psight competed with each other to gain strength and to teach the future generations to use their abilities. This competition became known as Psight, after the order itself.

In Psight, each player takes on the role of a psychic within the order of Psight. The goal is to defeat your opponents using your various Powers, Memories, and Abilities. If you gain Dominance over a Domain, your road to victory may become easier, as your opponents will no longer be able to use any additional Powers, Memories, or Abilities from your Domain. However, plan your actions carefully, because one wrong move could easily spell defeat. With a well-planned strategy and a little luck, you can be the last psychic standing and claim victory!

Psight is a strategy card game designed for 2-4 players. The objective is to out think your opponent and be the last player with cards in your hand. It plays similar to many CCG's without the expense of constantly buying booster packs or individual cards. We strongly disbelieve in the pay-to-win gaming model so everything you need to play with up to 3 other friends or family members is included in the game!

Psight is also a color-blind gamer friendly game with the use of Domain names and symbols on every card in the game.

item.description:
Until Dawn is a solitaire card game in which you play as John Woods in an attempt to defend your small cabin from a zombie attack. With the help of your dog, Jasper, and a loaded shotgun, you must stave off the zombies attempting to breach the four entrances to the cabin, and survive until dawn.

Worse, Woods’ wife, Rebecca, is suffering from a zombie bite to the arm, and is doing everything in her power to keep from being overcome by the zombie infection.

Once the sun rises, the zombies disperse, and you can make your escape.

As John Woods, you can defend the cabin by building barricades, commanding Jasper to help, and using your limited supply of shotgun shells. When you have the chance, you can also help Rebecca treat her wound. You may do as many of these actions as you wish, but, when you choose to stop, the zombies will take as many turns as you did.

There are three types of zombies attacking the cabin, each represented by a different colored card. As the zombies attack, cards are drawn from the deck and placed at one of the four entrances to the cabin. Eventually, the zombies will gain enough strength to begin breaking in. If all four entrances are breached, you lose. Just before dawn, the zombies launch one final attack. If you survive this attack, the sun will finally rise and you can make your escape.

Until Dawn won Best Horror/Zombie/Monster Game and Best Artwork in the BGG 2012 PnP Contest. Thanks all who voted! All files are available on the Corvid Games website.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This is it. This is where the weathered parchment pinpointed the Temple of the Feathered Serpent, lost since the conquistadors who had drawn the map disappeared over 500 years ago.

Pushing aside the great cycad fronds from the clearing you see the ancient pyramid before you. The entrance, you know, is at the top.

Climbing, you hear those sounds coming from the jungle behind you again. Something has been tracking you, waiting for an easy meal. It doesn’t matter. The treasures of the Incas lie within this ziggurat and an entire jamboree of ravenous jaguars couldn’t turn you away now.

Pushing aside the stone door at the top, you begin to descend the slick stone steps. What could go wrong now that you’re so close?

Temple of the Feathered Serpent (TotFS) is a tile laying game where you you are trying to navigate the ever changing maze to escape an ancient temple. Watch out for the deadly jaguars and snakes. The monkeys might sneak up and steal your hard won treasures.

Hey Look! We have a microbadge:

link.value: Temple of the Feathered Serpent: Expansion Pack

item.description: Milky Way card game is a meditative set-making game with an emphasis on strategy and memory. By matching the terra cards' top borders (the seasons), left borders (elements) and centers (landscapes) - the card player can make sets to gain victory points. There are also cosmos cards which multiply the score for a particular set. Be careful: Not every cosmo card will offer positive points.

Fantastic and addictive game. 1-4 players. Normal game mode, map mode, and challenge mode.

Objective: Defeat gold dragon and conquer the magic land with holy runes.

Challenge mode: No map needed. Each player is level 4, and equips 6 runes and 6 scrolls randomly.

Brief Game Rules:
Beginning: each player chooses role card and its side (light or dark), and takes 1 rune and 1 scroll randomly. Next, put the pawn on the battle map (Wasteland-Start Cell) and is Level 1

Process: the active player rolls a dice and moves on the battle map from start cell to Boss cell to fight the boss. When passing Boss cell, the player may choose to challenge the boss or return to the Start cell. When winning the challenge, the player goes to the next map and upgrade one Level.

Battle with monster: player starts first. The player may choose to use ability, rune or scroll in each turn. Ability can only be used once each battle and may be played anytime; only 1 rune can be played in each turn, and tap the rune after its effect (taped rune cannot be used in the same battle unless returned to hand); only 1 scroll can be played in each turn, and remove the scroll from game after its effect. The monster attacks secondly. Choose a monster attack card each turn to activate monster action.

Battle with player: opposing side players can attack each other when their pawns placed in the same cell. Any player can challenge another player when the pawn placed in the Battle Field Cell. The attacker plays first. Each player may use ability, rune and scroll to attack the opponent.

Team with player: same side players can make team when their pawns placed in the same cell. When they attack monster as a team, monster uses the different monster attack card to each team member. When they are attacked by opposing side player, their team status is broken, and the opponent may choose to attack each team member separately.

Cool Factors:

 Normal game mode, map mode, and challenge mode
 Strategic battle with abilities, runes, and scrolls
 Dark and Light camp, Team mode, and Battle Arena

Cool Factors:

-Handy and addictive game
 -2 colors, wiz point and power cards
 -Easy to start and highly strategic

Description:
Fantastic, fast and addictive game with your family and friends. 3-6 players. 54 wiz cards and 6 power cards.

Play all your cards as soon as possible to get points or chips!

Brief rules:
Each round, the first player plays first, and other players follow in order. The “Point Rules” can be applied whatever 1 card or more cards are played. When a player wins a round and takes the lead in a new round, the player may get the wiz points on the cards he just played and use the wiz points to play power card...

Description:
Business Empire is designed based on economic, financial and management concept in real business world. It demonstrates how to accumulate wealth and develop wealth quotient.

Brief rules:

There are 3 phases in a player’s turn: the beginning phase, the operation phase and the ending phase.
1) The beginning phase: The active player can draw 1 card from top of the library. Then the player generates revenue and pays interest.
2) The operation phase: The active player can build assets; sell assets; borrow liability; refund liability; place deposit; use deposit, operation card and disaster card.
3) The ending phase: If the player has more than 8 cards in hand, the player should choose to discard extra cards.

Cool Factors:

 Simulation to real business world
 Disclose the secret to accumulate wealth
 Easy to start and highly strategic

name.value: Yams! A Game of Power and Glory in the South Pacific

item.description:
A strategy card game for 2-4 players. Players take up the roles of island chieftains in the Trobriand Islands in the Southwestern Pacific in the 1890s; chieftains are competing to become the new Paramount Chief of the islands. Over the span of several harvest seasons they gather followers and land, harvest yams which serve as the currency of the islands, host dramatic feasts, organize trading expeditions and use magic and deception to undermine each other. The game ends when the cards run out and the winner is determined by a counting of "prestige points," which are acquired through having worker or yam plot cards (worth 1 point each), winning feast cards from other players (3 points each) or kula cards which represent the legendary pieces of jewelry acquired on trade expeditions (worth 5 points each).

Yams! is based on the ethnographic works of legendary anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowksi working in modern-day Papua New Guinea in the 1910s.

item.description:
"Over the Hump Airlift Campaign 1942-1945" is a simulation of the airlift to China in World War II. The simulation includes 58 pages of rules and procedures, scenarios, counter sheets, and map sections.

There are 16 scenarios beginning with an introductory basic scenario involving one China National Aviation Corporation DC-3 type aircraft flying a pioneering path-finding flight from Assam, India across the Himalayas to Kunming, China. The second scenario brings in the US Army Air Force using C-47 type aircraft in flying fuel to China for Doolittle's Raiders that they would have used to fly from China to India after the Raid on Tokyo in early 1942. Scenarios continue chronologically capturing highlights of the airlift campaign and introducing in succession: C-87, C-46, C-109, and finally C-54 type aircraft. The final scenario provides for as many as 500 aircraft in a one day maximum effort that occurred on August 1st, 1945 when the Air Transport Command India-China Division made over 1,000 sorties and delivered more than 5,000 tons of cargo to China in a single 24-hour period. Scenarios provide historical average daily tonnage for comparison of player performance in running airlift operations.

There are four counter sheets on 8-1/2 inch by 11-inch pages with each 1/2-inch by 1/2-inch counter representing a single aircraft with its flight characteristics printed on the counter. There are eight map pages on 8-1/2 inch by 11-inch pages that can be trimmed to form a map approximately 16 inches by 40 inches with representations of geographic locations, terrain, and altitude bands for flying aircraft counters from India to China and returning for another load. Various simulation tracks, such as the tonnage delivered, time clock, morale and efficiency, loss rate, and search and rescue level are included on the map sections. The map also includes loading and turn around boxes at the air fields for tracking aircraft as they land, load or turn around, complete loading or turn-around, are cleared for takeoff, and take off on their next flight.

The simulation is available as a free download and is fully contained in an Adobe Acrobat file that prints out on 58 pages of 8-1/2 by 11-inch paper. The simulation includes some probability driven aspects of airlift operations, and three or more 10-sided dice can be used for these purposes. No dice are provided, and players will need to provide dice or other means of generating random numbers.

The simulation is designed for solitaire play. More than one player can participate by dividing aircraft types among players or dividing operating bases among players.

In the distant future, Penguins dominate the earth in the east and west, fighting for the supremacy of the earth.

Play is a game for two players divided into attacker and defender.

Players are divided into military forces and King penguins Emperor penguins.

Against the attacking card, do the defense.
A successful attack, you'll earn points according to the card walls.
Defense side, you can return fire so as not to give point to the attacker.

Place the card in the middle of the field three walls.

Player, published from a select My first card of each other. It can be used as a card during a round reinforcements.
One of the card walls, place the card.
The attacking side, select the attack walls. And to publish the card.
Defense side, then defense to expose any of my card was placed.
Remove the card Once the defense to attack. However, if you can not defense, removing the only card the defender.
Once the attacker's card remains, walls have been breached.
The attacker, walls to expose the card when you win, you earn points on the back of the card.

When you are finished, play the next round.

Victory or defeat is as follows.
â—If you won a ten point ahead of the chip within three rounds, is the victory of the attacking side.
â—If the round is over 3, less than 10 point is a victory for the defender.
â—During a round, three walls when you are exposed by the attack, the attacker's victory.
â—If, during the round, three walls has not been published even one is a victory for the defender.

CFOTD is a light and humorous board game where you play an office worker during the zombie apocalypse. Maneuver your token through an office building besieged by the armies of the undead to be the first to rescue the CEO and lead him safely to the exit.

Players also control their own zombie that they use to hamper and hinder other players and event cards can help you, hinder you, or give you helpful items to help you win.

Based on zombie B-movie cliches CFOTD brings the campiness of low budget movies into the office.

The eternally hungry pig has gulped up the die – when the little piglets on the hunt for burgers race towards the finishing line, you must press the belly of the pig to learn how far you can move it. Three piglets per player participate in the race along the burger spots. In your turn you press the belly of the big pig, the die tumbles and rolls and when it stops you know how far you can move one of your piglets. When your piglet ends its move on a spot with another piglet already there, you send this piglet back to the start. If you are the first to have three piglets in your personal burger finish, you win.

Card game made as a promotional item for Dettol, a very popular disinfectand in Britain. The game is endorsed by the Child Accident Protection Trust.

The cards consists of pairs of cards. One of the pair warns of a danger and the other gives advice on how to avoid that danger.

Three games are described in the rules. Keeping Me Safe is the main game. The first player places a danger card face up. The next player checks her hand and plays the advice card on top of it (if she holds it). If not the next player looks, and so on. Once a pair has been completed, the next player lays a danger card and the game proceeds until one player has used all their cards. He/she is the winner.

The other two games are more traditional, Snap and Pairs, but both are a little more difficult because the two cards that match are not mirror images which would be more usual in games of Snap or Pairs.

Who scored the Wembley goal? How big is a playing field? How many times Germany was the world champion? Which famous singer was formerly goalkeeper for Real Madrid? Which player has been hindered by the collision with a moose on his international duty?
48 question cards offer interesting facts and curiosities about the most wonderful thing in the world:
Answer correctly and get the card as a point. Player with the most cards after the deck is exhausted is the winner.

A playful encounter with the painter Albrecht Durer, this memory version. 18 masterpieces of the famous Renaissance artist must be collected after the memory testing, but not in pairs, but in quartets. Each image was divided into four parts, the players will now add back together. First you need to find two matching parts, they are designed to be found later in the game a fitting part, this may be set to. The displayed works are presented in detail in the accompanying booklet.

A second simpler version of Prestel's Art Game. Players learn the most beautiful masterpieces of art history in an entertaining way.

Turn the spinner, move on the game board. Each field represents a range of art and is associated with a task: do pantomime, describe paintings, answer the questions. 
A sharp eye and a good memory is needed. 
The winner is the first who has puzzled together all the parts of his painting.

Simple rules - similar to Trivial Pursuit and some party games - roll the die, move Your game-piece and answer question. If Your answer is correct get the pie of that category. Categories are: Pantomix, What is wanted, Forbidden Words, True or false etc.

Collect piece of pie from each available category to win the game.

1100 questions from eight areas of knowledge: arts and culture, history and politics, nature and environment, sports and games, general, technology and science, earth and sky, fairy tales and legends, you roll and pull, gets on the color fields a question from the corresponding Worth area, who answers correctly gets a chip and is to it again, who first collected a chip from every field of knowledge, wins.

item.description:
Electronically assisted knowledge and reaction game. There are 24 panels on both sides of the display and variety of topics, from animals to ABC and sports equipment. 
One player enters the code number of the card nad the question is answered. Both players simultaneously search for the perfect image and enter its number. Whoever answers correctly gets faster, the point. The display also shows the final score. Who won after an agreed number of tables the most games is the overall winner.

Quiz game with cards, 110 question and answer cards, and the areas of travel, transport, technology, nostalgia and motor sports. Dice is rolled and it shows the category from the card. 
Player who answer correctly first gets the card.
If there are no more cards left, player who has collected the most cards is the winner.

Promotional game for Pirelli

Game with similar mechanism with Trivial Pursuit, the questions relate to the work and training with the Red Cross. 200 question cards with questions in 5 areas of knowledge, including general education.
Object of the game is to collect card from each category to win the game.

In this special edition of Spiel des Wissens, based on the BBC TV series and the film of the same name, players travel round our planet. To be able to travel the must be able to answer questions. In this edition questions come from a general category called Nature and from 6 special so called worlds – mountain world, jungle world, ice world, cave world, deep sea world and desert world. –

On each question cards questions are separated into an easy and a hard section, two in each section. At the start of the game players decide together who gets which difficulty level throughout the game. Before each question the player decides if wants to answer question 1 or question 2 on the card.

You roll the die, move and answer a question.

From the introduction
"This is a simulation game of US strategic bombing raids from England and Italy on 25 February 1944, the last day of the `Big Week' offensive. Two or three players or teams direct the actions of the opposing air forces as they seek to inflict more damage than they suffer in this attritional contest."

UB Bombers from England and Italy move steadly towards their German targets while the US fighters seek to keep then protected from German fighter attack. Simple machanics mean the game is easy to learn, but the differing ranges of the fighters and speed of the bombers mean planning ahead is required. Not knowing when the Germans may attack and cause the fighters to drop their fuel tanks, and so have to return home make this harder than it sounds.

From the introduction -
"This is a simulation game of the battle of the Korsun pocket in Ukraine in January and February 1944. Two players or teams direct the actions of the German and Soviet forces as they seek to capture or regain territory and to inflict losses on the opposing forces while minimising their own losses."

The Russians try to create a pocket, and then destroy the German forces, while the Germans sek to free their trapped comrades. Simple, but subtle mechanisms, reflect trade offs between all out attacks and greater losses, and the mobility of armoured units.

From the introduction -

"This is a simple grand tactical simulation game of the interception of an escorted formation of multiengine daylight bombers during World War Two. Two players or teams direct the actions of the escorting and intercepting fighters as they seek to inflict losses on the opposing aircraft while minimising their own losses. In team play, each player controls one or more specific fighter units, depending on the number of players and the amount of time available."

The counters come in four different sizes, with each larger size corresponding to the next higher altitude band (hence giving an intuitive representation of height, since higher units appear closer and so larger from an overhead perspective).

One of the games in Philip Sabin's book "Simulating War", with counters and map downloadable from his website.

This game has now been published in a deluxe edition by Victory Point games, with full colour components and added historical scenarios.

A card game that feels like a mix of Mille Bornes and Rummy.

Each player has a hand of 8 cards. Players take turns in order; a turn consists of:
1. draw a card 
2. (optional) meld cards (face down), and/or change previous melds
3. discard a card.

The first card melded must always be a "start" card; followed by several number cards (forming one out of 5 legal combinations), and a "key" card as last card.
In addition, the game contains cards that mess with other players hands, or allow to claim a discarded card.

A round ends when one player has completed a combination (for example: start, two triplets, key). Each player gets points for the cards he melded. There are some ways to score bonus points.

The game is played in several rounds, until the score of one player reaches 35 points.

In Pyramidion, each player plays an Egyptian foreman in charge of a resource supply for the gigantic construction site of the Cheops pyramid. On your turn, you activate sites and play cards in order to gain the biggest influence on these sites. Each foreman will use his contacts among merchants, negotiators and torturers (!) to supply boats located in major cities of Egypt. These boats will set sail in the direction of Giza only when full capacity is reached with the resources they require. The foreman who most effectively furnishes the construction site – the one who first obtains ten victory points – will be rewarded by the Pharaoh himself.

Pyramidion is both a strategic and tactical game, with some luck involved and a lot of player interaction. Are you going to thwart others – or focus on your own success?

item.description:
In Captain Midnight’s Treasure, you take on the role of a pirate on a crew that has just returned from a very successful raid and now it’s time to divide the loot in typical pirate fashion, with dice!

Captain Midnight’s Treasure is a family friendly, easy to learn, fast paced dice game that provides for challenging strategic game decisions in a fun environment. This game will test your knowledge of odds and probabilities, as well as help you teach them to younger upcoming gamers, as you decide when to push your luck and roll again, or stay with what you have.

Game Play:
You have 5 dice and 3 rolls to get as much treasure as you can from the pot before everyone else does. The game starts off by rolling the dice to determine the Swabbie. After that each person rolls the dice, with the Swabbie going last, trying to get a Ship, Captain, and Crew, with the last two dice determining how much treasure you get.

But since you are pirates, it’s not going to be that easy! First, you have to make sure you get enough treasure to beat the Swabbie or else you have to pay him his dues. Then, certain rolls will cause you to lose your treasure or allow you to take treasure from other players, or even become Captain Midnight himself!

And of course the one with the most gold at the end wins!

Welcome to the world of Diggin Deep: World’s Game, brought to you by Diggin Deep Sports. With this game, you should be able to re-create a match of soccer complete with all the decisions that the coach would make. You decide who to dress and who to scratch. You decide who to start and who to save as a substitute. You name the starting keeper. There are also plenty of ‘in game’ decisions to make. Do I take a shot from the scoring zone, or try to penetrate for a better scoring chance. If the game is tied late in the second half, do I play conservative, or do I play aggressive and go for the win? My star midfielder just collapsed due to heat exhaustion. How do I replace his offense? How do I replace his defense? Once you have a solid understanding of the cards, charts, and gameplay, you should be able to play a full regulation match in about thirty minutes.
 
The game is played using three ten sided dice and player cards that represent their abilities on the pitch. Some players can actually 'dig deep' in certain game situations to tilt the scales in their favor. It's all here as you attempt to bring glory to your squad.

In this daring game of adventure, you race through the twisting maze of Montezuma's Treasury collecting artifacts as you attempt to reach the Treasure room.

But beware, each tile you or an opponent lay can twist your path and lead you away from the Treasure. Each tile may reward you with an artifact, but chances are they are laced with deadly hazards that your opponents can trigger through drafting an Event card; crushing walls, pits, spikes, trap doors, shooting arrows, rotating rooms, and a boulder that rolls across the board.

Using your action points, pick up items in your adventure to help navigate past these hazards. Scramble through secret passageways, fight off dangerous creatures, activate secret doors and find your way through pitch black rooms. That map you found might be of help, but chances are the path behind you will cave in.

Even if you can't make it to the Treasure room you might have enough to win if you were able to collect enough Items with treasure points or Artifacts that are scattered throughout the Treasury.

For every hidden door you open, boulder that rolls through the maze, crushing walls that close, spikes that rise, trap door that opens you are impacting another area of the map as you move those tokens to a new area of the map. This might buy you enough time to find an exit with your arms full of riches. First one out watches the Treasury collapse from the inside out, chasing out or trapping everyone else inside!

Balance the Item cards you'll need to get out with the treasure you need to win, because the player that makes it out alive with the most treasure points in their hand wins!



Each players turn consists of 3 steps:
(1) Draft one Event card. 
 Event cards include triggering specific hazards on tiles (i.e. Arrows, Spikes, Rotating a room, Secret passageways)
 and attacking other players through Thieves, Spiders and Rats event cards.(2) Perform 2 of the following actions
 Move, Move, Take Item (cards), Play Item card, Rest (raise health by 1), take Treasure cards when in the treasure room

(3) Place new map tiles adjacent to the tiles your token is on.

Game Components


 1 Board
 12 Artifact Cards
 20 Event Cards (12 unique)
 38 Treasure Cards
 51 Item Cards (10 unique)
 1 Die to resolve conflict
 4 Player Adventure Markers
 4 Player Health Markers
 1 Bag
 Rules



 90 Map Tiles
 1 Treasure Room tile 
 3 Raised Spikes Tokens
 4 Door Tokens
 2 Open Trap Door Tokens
 1 Boulder Token
 1 Crushing Wall Token
